ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A familiarity with literature on sensation, the senses, materiality, and religion; experience crafting a project in line with the classes focus, as well as my own.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The reading list was a strength, as was the attention given to individual projects, the opportunity to collaborate with the Freer project, and the investment of Prof. Promey in her students. Conversation lagged at points, and did not dive into the readings in a thorough or specific way.
the content as far as the readings i thought was really interesting but i felt that the class discussion was often lacking in vibrancy

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if they have a specific project in mind that would fit well with the course, or if they have an established interest in materiality, etc.
yes, good for people wanting to integrate religious studies interests with art history
